bib_record.title: -Neutron total cross sections of Pu-239 from transmis- sion measurements in the energy range of 1 to 500 keV.

free_txt: H.Derrien
Experimental site.
Main reference
The Oak Ridge electron linac (ORELA)
was used as a pulsed neutron source in a high
resolution transmission experiment by Harvey et al.
Resonance parameters from REL-REF were used to test
method by calculation of average effective cross
sections of three samples and total cross section in
8 energy intervals (Table2 of reference).
To derive extrapolated to zero-thickness cross
sections in energy range 1.-10.keV the average exp.
effective cross sections from three samples
transmissions were used.In energy range 10. - 500.keV
the average effective cross sections from thick sample
transmission were used.
The data were corrected for the following effects.
1) background
2) self-shielding
Here Derrien corrects and extrapolates results of
transmission measurements carried out by Harvey et al.
at Oak Ridge and presented by Harvey et al at
proceedings  of the international Conf. for Nucl.Data
for Science and Technol., Mito 1988,page 115, JAERI.
Statistical uncertainties and systematic errors.
The systematic errors on the transmission data
of Harvey were  as follows
-1 % from normalization factor
-0.3 % on transmission between resonances
from background evaluation.
-Error due to self-shielding correction.
-Cross section error due to systematic error on
transmission measurements.
Statistical error was negligible.
-Absolute total error due to extrapolation (including
systematic error on transmission measurement).
The Oak Ridge electron linac (ORELA)
was used as a pulsed neutron source in a high
resolution transmission experiment by Harvey et al.
Neutrons in the energy range 0.5eV to 500 eV
were produced by spallation reaction using ORELA.
The accelerator pulse width was 16ns.
The neutron spectrum was measured by TOF techniques.
The flight path length 80.394m and the TOF
channel width 8 to 64ns.
High resolution transmission measurements were
carried out by Harvey et Al. Analysis and corrections
for resonance self-shielding to yield average
corrected total cross sections for Pu239 were carried
out by Derrien using data obtained with various sample
thicknesses. MONTE CARLO method was used to obtain
resonance parameters and thus simulate the true and
effective X-sections. Calculations, including Doppler
and resolution broadening were done using the code
SAMMY.
Data of resonance
parameters used in analysis.
Three Pu239 samples of thickness 0.00646, 0.01825 and
0.07471 at/B were used. The sample effective
temperature was 106(5)K.
Data from main ref., Tables 4,5,6.
